awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 24th ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports students at U.S. institutions to attend the Twenty-fourth ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2023). HotMobile 2023, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, is held in Orange County, CA, February 22-23, 2023. 
HotMobile is the premier workshop targeting mobile computing and system integration fields. Attending this event will benefit the scientific progress of the student's research. The exposure to the technical content of HotMobile 2023 will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields, with a long-term benefit of scientific advances in mobile computing.

Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending this workshop but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, applications from female and underrepresented groups in mobile computing research will be strongly encouraged. Approximately 20 students will receive travel grants from this award to attend HotMobile 2023.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supports students at U.S. institutions in attending the 24th ACM Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2023). HotMobile, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, was held in Orange County, CA, February 22-23, 2023.

HotMobile 2023 provides a high-caliber forum to present innovative and significant research on the design, implementation, usage, and evaluation of mobile systems, applications, and services. HotMobile seeks papers that focus primarily on systems and applications and propose new research directions, advocate non-traditional approaches to old (or new) ideas, or generate controversy and discussion. The workshop especially encourages papers that identify fundamental open questions, advocate a new approach, offer a constructive critique of the state-of-the-art, debunk existing assumptions, report unexpected early results, report on promising but unproven ideas, or propose new evaluation methods. The research and development results reported in HotMobile workshops span multiple disciplines, including wireless communication, mobile applications, wearable computing, vehicular wireless systems, personal area networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, data management, scheduling, sensors, security, and privacy. HotMobile seeks to provide a cross-disciplinary venue for researchers addressing the design of mobile computing in the context of an integrated system. The 2023 workshop continues the tradition that the HotMobile workshop series has established as the premiere workshop on mobile computing. The travel funds allow graduate students conducting research in the field to attend technical presentations, be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students, thereby making contacts potentially critical to their careers and future success. The impact on the students’ careers from attending HotMobile 2023 is substantial.

The travel grant application process was advertised via the HotMobile 2023 website, posts on Facebook and Twitter through official accounts and through multiple mailing lists. A selection committee of four individuals from the HotMobile organizing committee and technical program committee reviewed the applications, and decisions were made primarily based on merit, including the applicant’s interests and accomplishments in the mobile systems, applications, and services research space. The committee put preferences to the female and other URM candidates and the first-time attendees.

A total of 21 students were selected to receive travel awards and successfully attended the workshop out of 24 applicants. Nine (9) of the travel grant awardees identified themselves as female or URM candidates (42.8%). Seventeen (17) of the travel grant awardees were attending any HotMobile workshop for the first time (80.9%). Awardees were notified of their selection and travel grant allocation through email. The awardees engaged in various discussions, presentations, and demonstrations throughout the workshop and produced written insights on select events. Moreover, the awardees organized and participated in a panel discussion and networking event on “Diversity and Inclusion: What? Why? How?” This event invited students and faculty members to share their opinions, experiences, challenges, and success stories regarding diversity and inclusion in academia.


Last Modified: 01/08/2024
Modified by: Nirupam Roy
